title: Unilateral Conductive Hearing Loss Post-Trauma
chief_complaint: Since my car accident 3 months ago, sounds seem muffled in my left ear and I am having trouble telling where sounds are coming from.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset 3 months ago following a motor vehicle accident.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty localizing sounds. Denies otalgia, pressure, tinnitus, or dizziness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Perception of muffled sounds and localization deficits.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Determine the cause of hearing loss and management options.

history.present_illness: Patient reports being involved in a car accident 3 months prior. Since then, he has experienced difficulty hearing in the left ear.
history.otologic_history: Denies otalgia, pressure, tinnitus, or dizziness.
history.noise_exposure_history: No reported history of noise exposure.
history.patient_goals: Evaluation of left ear hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal hearing thresholds (0-10 dB HL). Left ear shows a conductive hearing loss ranging from slight (low freqs) to moderately severe (high freqs) with significant air-bone gaps. Bone conduction is normal bilaterally.

numeric_results.LT_AC_Thresholds: 25 dB at 250Hz sloping to 60-70 dB at 8000Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT is consistent with PTA bilaterally. Word recognition scores are excellent in both ears.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear tympanogram is normal (Type A). Left ear tympanogram is hypercompliant (Type Ad), suggesting ossicular discontinuity.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral reflexes present; Right contralateral reflexes elevated. Left ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes are absent.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a conductive hearing loss in the left ear. The left ear exhibits a significant air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds. Immittance testing reveals a hypercompliant (Type Ad) tympanogram on the left and absent acoustic reflexes, consistent with an ossicular discontinuity likely resulting from the recent head trauma.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms a 'conductive' hearing loss in the left ear, meaning sound is not being conducted efficiently to the inner ear.

The pressure test (tympanometry) shows your eardrum is moving more than normal (floppy), which, combined with the hearing loss, suggests a disconnection in the tiny bones behind the eardrum (ossicular discontinuity) caused by the car accident.
We recommend a referral to an Ear, Nose, and Throat (ENT) physician to discuss surgical options to repair the connection.
If surgery is not pursued or is unsuccessful, a hearing aid for the left ear is a viable option to restore balance to your hearing.
notes_for_actor: Portray a 31-year-old male who is generally healthy but frustrated by the change in hearing since the accident.
You do not have pain or dizziness, but you should emphasize that sounds feel 'muffled' on the left side.
Mention that you have trouble telling where sounds are coming from (localization), which is a common symptom of unilateral loss.
